Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art on the side of an upright boulder, showing the pecked, infilled figures of a bull, gazelle and three unidentified quadruped animals, all upright. The bull is central and faces left, with either short horns or ears visible. Above it stands a gazelle which has a long neck and similar-shaped ears/horns. To the left of the bull is an unidentified quadruped figure with a small body and short legs but a very long neck and no head, facing right. To the left of this is another small unidentified animal facing left and to the lower left of this across a natural ridge in the rock is another, facing left with front quarters not clearly visible. A 5cm photo scale has been fitted at the base of the image. Wadi Hamra, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Wadi Hamra is a canyon-like valley with a relatively flat floor between one and 200m wide, curling more or less south into the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s Western Desert. There are three known rock art sites, all for engravings and first reported by Has Rhotert in 1952: The first is an old river terrace with numerous engravings of giraffe and a few of ostrich, cattle and abstract fan-shaped grooves, with stone circles and shallow depressions on the top. The second is several engravings further southwest. The third stands opposite the branch containing the first site: a rocky outcrop about 15 m high with a number of engravings along the base.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
